title: Corrections: May 21, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, May 21, 2020.
content: An article on Wednesday about difficulties faced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain in Parliament misspelled the given name of the speaker of the House of Commons. He is Lindsay Hoyle, not Lyndsey Hoyle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa L. Lewis
title: When Teen Boys Use Supplements
description: Some supplements are more effective than others — and some may be harmful, experts warn.
content: “I’ve started cutting,” my son, a college freshman, recently told me. He meant he was temporarily restricting calories to lose body fat as part of his new focus on bodybuilding. He planned to alternate cutting with “bulking,” or building up muscle mass, aided by over-the-counter supplements like protein powder and creatine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: Religious services with up to 10 people can resume today in New York, while restaurants, stores and malls have opened in Connecticut.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Vaccines, U.S. Reopenings, Flour Frenzy: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: An Absurdist Noir Novel Shows Yukio Mishima’s Lighter Side
description: In “Life for Sale,” a young copywriter fails at suicide, offers his life up in the classifieds and has a series of misadventures.
content: Like many great and prolific writers, Yukio Mishima divided his time. His best novels, including the Sea of Fertility tetralogy, were sweeping works tinged with his nationalist right-wing politics but also full of universal profundity. These are the types of books that made him a three-time nominee for the Nobel Prize in Literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, Jackson Heights and Manhattan’s financial district.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Most Popular Properties of April
description: The most popular real estate listings of April are a mixed bag of commercial and residential properties.
content: The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has wreaked havoc on the real estate industry, reducing the number of available listings and altering priorities for both buyers and sellers. We can see the impact as we look at the five most-viewed listings in April on The New York Times’s Find a Home site — a collection of residential and business spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Robots! (Don’t Get Too Excited.)
description: Robots are cool. But we should be skeptical of emerging technology.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Katie Benner and William K. Rashbaum
title: Michael Cohen, Ex-Trump Lawyer, Leaves Prison Early Because of Virus
description: Mr. Cohen, who pleaded guilty to campaign finance violations and other crimes, had been imprisoned at a minimum-security camp in New York.
content: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s former personal lawyer and fixer, was released from a federal prison on Thursday on furlough and returned to his home in Manhattan, one of his lawyers said. He had asked to be released over health concerns tied to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, Jackson Heights and Manhattan’s financial district.
content: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, Jackson Heights and Manhattan’s financial district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa L. Lewis
title: When Teen Boys Use Supplements
description: Some supplements are more effective than others — and some may be harmful, experts warn.
content: “I’ve started cutting,” my son, a college freshman, recently told me. He meant he was temporarily restricting calories to lose body fat as part of his new focus on bodybuilding. He planned to alternate cutting with “bulking,” or building up muscle mass, aided by over-the-counter supplements like protein powder and creatine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: 2 Dead in Manhattan as Police Interrupt Domestic Attack
description: The police fatally shot a transit worker who had just killed his sister-in-law and wounded a building superintendent in a Harlem apartment.
content: Two sisters were having dinner on Wednesday evening with a superintendent in the Harlem apartment building where he worked when there was a knock at the door.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: Religious services with up to 10 people can resume today in New York, while restaurants, stores and malls have opened in Connecticut.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: The Truth About Cocoons
description: What caterpillars really go through in there has applications for our moment.
content: What caterpillars really go through in there has applications for our moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: How to Protect Kids’ Ears From Constant Headphone Use
description: Volume is not the only measure to consider. Duration also contributes to damage to our kids’ ears.
content: Children glued to their headphones. It’s a familiar scene these days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Yo-Yo Ma Would Invite Socrates to Dinner
description: “For once, I’d like to ask the questions.”
content: “For once, I’d like to ask the questions,” says the renowned cellist, whose new ensemble album is “Not Our First Goat Rodeo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: When the Children Needed Their Own Rooms, This Manhattan Family Had to Move. Which of These Homes Would You Choose?
description: Finding extra space for everyone was a priority — even before the pandemic forced these New Yorkers to spend all their time at home together.
content: Finding extra space for everyone was a priority — even before the pandemic forced these New Yorkers to spend all their time at home together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: Charlie Brooker Saw All This Coming
description: The “Black Mirror” creator, who knows something about dystopias, discusses the cognitive dissonance of this “boring apocalypse” and the continued importance of satire.
content: LONDON — Charlie Brooker may have been more prepared than most for the coronavirus and the subsequent global lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Lucky Grandma’ Review: Mean Streets of Chinatown
description: In Sasie Sealy’s darkly funny mafia thriller, the veteran actress Tsai Chin exudes cool.
content: Cantankerous and fiercely independent, the 80-year-old Grandma Wong (Tsai Chin) wants to live by herself in her Chinatown apartment in New York. Her son, Howard (Eddie Yu), wants her to move in with his family to save on rent. Encouraged by a fortune teller’s promise of imminent luck, she takes all her savings to a casino only to find herself — after some hilariously absurd twists — with a bagful of a dead man’s cash and a pair of gangsters on her tail.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Fraud Reported as Jobless Claims Reach 38.6 Million
description: President Trump, visiting a Michigan factory, again refused to wear a mask in public. Flags were ordered lowered for Memorial Day weekend in memory of those who died from the virus.
content: A sophisticated fraud network targeting Washington State’s unemployment system claimed hundreds of millions of dollars before officials were able to identify and crack down on the coordinated attack, state officials said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Go on a First Date During Quarantine
description: Being alone is tough. Here are some ways to go on a first date in isolation.
content: If you want to go on a first date, take advantage of what you can uniquely do in this moment. For starters, you can now see into other people’s houses without the expectation of hooking up. You can see so much of their actual lives before meeting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: Susan Rothenberg, Acclaimed Figurative Painter, Dies at 75
description: Her raw renditions of horses and other figures breathed new life into painting when the genre was under siege in 1970s SoHo.
content: Susan Rothenberg, whose flayed, lushly foreboding paintings radiated a Paleolithic grandeur and helped usher figuration back into an art world that had declared it extinct in the 1970s, died on Monday at her home in Galisteo, N.M. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Lucky Peterson, a Bluesman Since He Was a Boy, Dies at 55
description: He cut a record at 5 and went on to a steady if somewhat under-the-radar career as a backing musician and solo artist.
content: In his recent concerts the bluesman Lucky Peterson, who died on Sunday in Dallas, had been celebrating his 50th anniversary in show business. That was striking considering that Mr. Peterson, at his death, was only 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Ronald Shurer II, Cited for Bravery in Afghanistan, Dies at 41
description: An Army medic, Staff Sergeant Shurer charged into heavy gunfire, saving fellow soldiers. He was awarded the Medal of Honor.
content: Staff Sergeant Ronald Shurer II, who received the Medal of Honor, the nation’s highest military decoration, for braving heavy gunfire to save lives in the war in Afghanistan, died on May 14 at a hospital in Washington. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Getting on a Plane? Please Take the Food Out of Your Bag
description: New security and health policies at airports and on planes will make traveling this summer a bit stranger and, officials hope, safer.
content: Airports this Memorial Day weekend are likely to be far emptier than usual, but people who plan to travel can expect to encounter lots of changes and new inconveniences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: How the Pandemic Splintered the Appalachian Trail
description: The coronavirus scuttled plans and forced officials to ask people to get out of the woods. Of the thousands who hoped to hike the trail this year, only a few hundred remain.
content: When Kelsey Foster started hiking the Appalachian Trail in early March, she had left her whole life behind — her job, her apartment, her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Block Surgery for Transgender Inmate
description: The prisoner, Adree Edmo, said Idaho’s failure to provide the procedure violated the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday turned down a request from Idaho prison officials to block court-ordered sex reassignment surgery for a transgender prisoner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: ‘Expect More’: Climate Change Raises Risk of Dam Failures
description: Engineers say most dams in the United States, designed decades ago, are unsuited to a warmer world and stronger storms.
content: The dam that failed in Central Michigan on Tuesday gave way for the same reason most do: It was overwhelmed by water. Almost five inches of rain fell in the area in the previous two days, after earlier storms had saturated the ground and swollen the Tittabawassee River, which the dam held back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: Five Art Books to Read This Summer
description: As the art world mulls whether a return to “normalcy” should be its goal, publishers mine the archives of artists who found their own counterpaths.
content: For much of the culture industry, as with society at large, a single pressing issue looms over all others: Join the rush to reopen? Or remain anxiously hunkered down, lest — like the fake ending of so many horror movies — the seemingly defeated killer suddenly re-emerges from his hiding spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: University of California Will End Use of SAT and ACT in Admissions
description: The change is expected to accelerate the momentum of American colleges away from the tests, amid concern that they are unfair to poor, black and Hispanic students.
content: SACRAMENTO — The University of California on Thursday voted to phase out the SAT and ACT as requirements to apply to its system of 10 schools, which include some of the nation’s most popular campuses, in a decision with major implications for the use of standardized tests in college admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Many Will Die for the Dow?
description: In a pandemic, Trump is reverting to type.
content: In mid-March, after weeks in denial, Donald Trump finally admitted that Covid-19 was a serious threat and called on Americans to practice social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Lash and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Will Hot Weather Kill the Coronavirus Where You Live?
description: Trump says warm weather “kills this kind of virus.” Is he right?
content: Trump says warm weather “kills this kind of virus.” Is he right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Daley
title: Republicans Have a New Plan to Thwart the Will of the People
description: A Missouri initiative would undo voters’ preference for nonpartisan legislative districts — and perhaps shift representation itself.
content: When Karl Rove laid out the Republican plan to win back power by weaponizing redistricting in a March 2010 op-ed, Democrats failed to pay proper attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Morrison
title: Russia Flouts Another Treaty. So We’re Leaving It.
description: The agreement undermines security instead of promoting it.
content: Arms control treaties can be a powerful national security tool. But too often arms control proponents — those who seek to control weapons by agreement — get confused: Is arms control a means to a national security end or the end itself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: How to Lower the Risk of Infection at Summer Camps
description: Our goal should be to make the benefits outweigh any potential harm.
content: Summer is coming fast, and parents are beginning to panic about camp. They don’t know whether it’s safe for their kids to go.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Some Survivors, the Stigma of Illness Far Outlasts Its Symptoms
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 21, 2020.
content: “We’re like the chosen ones. We can go back into society, we can donate plasma, we are very valuable. But to people who are afraid of catching it, we are like pariahs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: To Compare an Apple to a Submarine
description: Perchance to dream?
content: Is it fair to compare Quibi, a floundering new platform for professionally produced bite-size video entertainment, to TikTok, an immensely popular platform for user-generated bite-size video entertainment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Andrew Lloyd Webber: Now, Yesterday and Tomorrow
description: Online broadcasts of some of the composer’s greatest hits put the spotlight on a 50-year career.
content: LONDON — It’s not every day you get to hear a composer singing along to a show he wrote nearly 40 years ago. But one of the unexpected pleasures of life in lockdown has been the availability, onscreen at least, of some people you might not expect to pop up in real time on YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan, Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Trump’s Vaccine Chief Has Vast Ties to Drug Industry, Posing Possible Conflicts
description: Moncef Slaoui, a former pharmaceutical executive, is now overseeing the U.S. initiative to develop coronavirus treatments and vaccines. His financial interests and corporate roles have come under scrutiny.
content: The chief scientist brought on to lead the Trump administration’s vaccine efforts has spent the last several days trying to disentangle pieces of his stock portfolio and his intricate ties to big pharmaceutical interests, as critics point to the potential for significant conflicts of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are in Ardsley, N.Y., and Fairfield, Conn.
content: This week’s properties are in Ardsley, N.Y., and Fairfield, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: Why Is This Chocolate Shimmering Like a Rainbow?
description: This tasty treat is additive free, and it turns iridescent with a little help from physics.
content: Earlier this month, Samy Kamkar shared his latest creation on Twitter: chocolate that shimmers like a rainbow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: ‘Smash,’ NBC’s Short-Lived Musical Drama, Eyes the Stage
description: Steven Spielberg and other original producers are adapting the backstage TV series, which theater fans continued to embrace after its brief run.
content: The NBC drama “Smash,” though both loved and abhorred when it premiered in 2012, has since grown into a cult favorite among theater buffs. There were flashy musical numbers! Christian Borle sitting at a piano! The high stakes of putting on a show! (Critics were less thrilled.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz and Campbell Robertson
title: Lockdown Delays Cost at Least 36,000 Lives, Data Show
description: Even small differences in timing would have prevented the worst exponential growth, which by April had subsumed New York City, New Orleans and other major cities, researchers found.
content: If the United States had begun imposing social distancing measures one week earlier than it did in March, about 36,000 fewer people would have died in the coronavirus outbreak, according to new estimates from Columbia University disease modelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: G.O.P. Voters Back QAnon Conspiracy Promoter for U.S. Senate
description: Jo Rae Perkins won her primary campaign in Oregon as the QAnon conspiracy theory has continued to gain momentum in Republican circles.
content: SEATTLE — Republicans in Oregon have selected a Senate candidate who promotes the QAnon conspiracy theory, the latest sign that conservatives are increasingly willing to embrace a movement built on a baseless series of plotlines about President Trump battling a shadowy globalist cabal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Japanese Theater
description: Andrew Kingsley colors our world.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I love puzzles that require an additional element to figure out the theme. It’s like an extra gift from the puzzle maker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: What About the Plants?
description: The greenery left behind by New Yorkers during the pandemic may not survive until the lockdown ends. But some who stayed behind are working to keep the plants alive.
content: Like many of his friends, Jake Foster considered leaving his Brooklyn apartment and retreating to his parents’ home in Dallas to escape the endless drumbeat of coronavirus. But first he had to devise a plan for his 60 house plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Inaction That Cost Lives
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: By the final days of February, many public health experts were sounding the alarm about the coronavirus, and some people were listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Putting a Stamp (or Not) on Vote-by-Mail
description: President Trump makes false claims, and Mike Pompeo faces scrutiny: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump at a coronavirus meeting with Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas and Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas at the White House on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘What We Know About Your Chances of Catching the Virus Outdoors’
description: All 50 states have begun to reopen to some degree. In this lesson, students will learn about the risks in going outdoors again — and precautions they can take to minimize them.
content: Featured Article: “What We Know About Your Chances of Catching the Virus Outdoors” by Michael Levenson, Tara Parker-Pope and James Gorman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Taitz
title: How to Reduce Your Risk of PTSD in a Post-Covid-19 World
description: It’s normal to feel a sense of hopelessness and loneliness in these times. But there are proven and proactive ways for you to get through it.
content: “When will this end? And if it ever does, will I be OK?!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Delavan
title: How to Refresh Your Home With Minimal Fuss
description: From reconsidering your lighting to upgrading your bedding, suggestions for making the space you’re isolating in feel new again.
content: If you’re lucky enough to be healthy but bored, having already reorganized your spice rack and closet, you might be in need of another project to fill some of the remaining hours of self-isolation. Perhaps, like many of us, you’re also feeling overly familiar with every contour and corner of your home, and are longing for a not-too-daunting, not-too-costly way to refresh it. Here are a few simple home-décor projects you can accomplish without the need for outside help. While none is a huge undertaking — no power tools or wall removal required — each can have an outsize effect, turning a room you’re all too used to into a space that feels at least somewhat new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: How Long Will It Take for the Economy to Recover?
description: Paul Krugman thinks it could be quick. But he also thinks Paul Krugman could be wrong.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Tony Hawk’s 900 Spin Was Amazing. An 11-Year-Old Skateboarder Stuck a 1080.
description: That’s three full spins before landing back on the halfpipe for Gui Khury.
content: Gui Khury owned a skateboard before he was even born, thanks to his father, Ricardo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Rhody McCoy, Key Figure in New York’s School Wars, Dies at 97
description: He headed the Brooklyn district where teacher transfers in 1968 sparked a bitter, racially-charged dispute over union seniority and community control.
content: Rhody McCoy, a veteran black educator whose peremptory transfer of white teachers from his Brooklyn school district in 1968 touched off a citywide strike that closed schools for weeks and exposed a seismic rift among American liberals over race, education and trade unionism, died on April 18 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx and Katherine Schulten
title: Election 2020: 11 Ways to Engage Students From Now Until November
description: Predicting the unpredictable, adopting an issue and other ideas for teaching and learning about the election.
content: Though election news will dominate the headlines all summer, the global pandemic has thrown into question everything from how the candidates will campaign to whether there will be live conventions to how we’ll vote in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray and Julie Bosman
title: As Virus Lingers in Michigan, a New Crisis Arrives: Flooding
description: Thousands of residents of Midland, Mich., fled their homes as waters rose, trying to keep at a safe social distance even in shelters.
content: MIDLAND, Mich. — Along Main Street in the central Michigan city of Midland, residents crowded the sidewalk on Wednesday, watching the rising waters of the Tittabawassee River in stunned despair. Floodwaters lapped less than a block away, and a row of businesses, their electricity cut off, stood dark and quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Coronavirus Changed China’s Big Political Event. Here’s What to Expect.
description: The National People’s Congress, which starts Friday morning in Beijing, is a chance for China to show the world that it has tamed the epidemic.
content: China’s biggest event on the political calendar, the annual session of the National People’s Congress, is always a tightly choreographed legislative pageant aimed at conveying the strength of the ruling Communist Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: The 1975: Self-Aware, Self-Indulgent and, Yes, Sincere
description: The British band’s new album, “Notes on a Conditional Form,” is a more downcast take on the challenges of living in the internet age.
content: The 1975 is a British pop band, not a graduate seminar’s sparsely attended lecture series, though the titles of its most recent albums certainly invite that clarification. The bold, eclectic “A Brief Inquiry Into Online Relationships” from 2018 found the verbose, self-aware frontman Matty Healy moving deftly between arena-sized anthems and confessional ballads, serving up cheeky Twitter-era bons mots on the pitfalls of fame, mortality and contemporary life. (“Danny says we’re living in a simulation,” he sang, “but he works in a petrol station.”) Now, a year and a half later, comes the 200-level curriculum: “Notes on a Conditional Form.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Villain’ Review: Brothers in Harm
description: An aging ex-con is forced into old ways in this superior crime thriller.
content: Any movie containing the line “You need to grab that hacksaw and start on his legs” is already halfway to winning me over, and Philip Barantini’s “Villain” does not disappoint. Populated by men with fists like shovels and faces like bruised fruit, this British crime drama has, for all its grime and gutter maneuvering, an unusual, mournful dignity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Survive the Night’ Review: Droning Through a Home Invasion
description: As bored as Bruce Willis has looked in recent movies, you can’t expect him to muster much interest in this home invasion thriller.
content: Bruce Willis was doing his part for video on demand even before the pandemic made it the norm for watching movies. In recent years, he has cultivated a side gig droning through supporting roles in uninspired thrillers that barely surface in theaters. The latest obscurity is “Survive the Night,” a flabby hunk of meat that the director, Matt Eskandari, hasn’t bothered to season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Voelk
title: Rise of S.U.V.s: Leaving Cars in Their Dust, With No Signs of Slowing
description: Sport utility vehicles outsold sedans two to one in 2019, just four years after surpassing them for the first time. This shift shows little sign of stopping.
content: Trends come and go. Affordable big-screen TVs and craft beer are welcome to stay. Small-plate restaurants and leisure suits? We’ll live when they’re gone. Last year in the United States, S.U.V.s outsold sedans two to one, a trend years in the making that experts expect will only grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Approves John Ratcliffe for Top Intelligence Job in Sharply Split Vote
description: The congressman from Texas was confirmed by a divided Senate to take over an office at the center of the Trump administration’s investigations of Obama administration officials.
content: WASHINGTON — A divided Senate voted on Thursday to confirm Representative John Ratcliffe of Texas, a fierce conservative ally of President Trump’s with relatively little intelligence experience, to lead the nation’s spy agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Unit That Prosecuted Roger Stone Is Reorganized
description: The overhaul of a division of the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington came at the end of a brief tenure by a longtime adviser to Attorney General William P. Barr.
content: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials have restructured the division of federal prosecutors that oversaw the case against President Trump’s longtime friend Roger J. Stone Jr., according to people briefed on the matter, the latest upheaval in an office at the center of the recent political turmoil at the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Atlantic Lays Off 68, Citing ‘a Bracing Decline in Advertising’
description: Despite the addition of 90,000 subscribers since March, the venerable publication says it has fallen victim to the pandemic’s economic fallout.
content: The Atlantic appeared to have the right ingredients for a successful 21st-century publication: strong journalism, a thriving digital operation and the enthusiastic backing of a multibillionaire, Laurene Powell Jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: As the Restaurant Industry Struggles, the President Talks About Butter
description: A White House meeting with hospitality executives this week did little to clarify plans for millions of affected workers.
content: I once knocked on the back door of a cheesemonger in Brooklyn and waited outside for a lump of hard-to-find, extremely expensive, unmarked butter produced by Diane St. Clair at her tiny creamery in Orwell, Vt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
title: Pompeo Quietly Visits Conservative Donors and Political Figures on State Dept. Trips
description: The meetings, often kept off his public schedule, have taken place as Mike Pompeo nurtures plans for a presidential bid in 2024 and as he considered a run for the Senate from Kansas.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made a secretive trip in January to a Florida retirement enclave populated by prominent Republican donors while on the tail end of a diplomatic trip to Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: One Beach’s Summer Virus Plan: 197 Groups in Zones 18-Feet Square
description: The virus has upended summer rhythms at the Jersey Shore, a 130-mile coastline that is equal parts economic engine and cultural touchstone.
content: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J. — One lifeguard will sit perched on a tall wooden chair. Two others, maintaining distance, will stand sentinel on the beach below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: These Labs Rushed to Test for Coronavirus. They Had Few Takers.
description: The fragmented U.S. health care system has hampered efforts to expand coronavirus testing, by making it difficult for hospitals to switch to new labs with ample capacity.
content: When a stay-at-home order in March all but closed the revered labs of the gene-editing pioneer Jennifer Doudna, her team at the University of California, Berkeley dropped everything and started testing for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: After New Coronavirus Outbreaks, China Imposes Wuhan-Style Lockdown
description: Infections in the northeast have led officials to sequester hundreds of thousands at home. “China doesn’t want to take any chances,” one expert said.
content: In Shulan, a city in China’s northeast, the streets are eerily quiet, devoid of taxis and buses. Apartment complexes have been sealed off, confining residents inside. Teams of government workers go door to door rounding up sick people as part of what they call a “wartime” campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Sameer Yasir
title: Cyclone Amphan’s Death Toll Rises to 80 in India and Bangladesh
description: The worst damage was reported in the Indian state of West Bengal, home to the metropolis Kolkata and many small, coastal villages.
content: NEW DELHI — More than 80 people were killed by the powerful cyclone that slammed into India and Bangladesh on Wednesday, wiping out thousands of homes and drenching low-lying areas in torrential rain, officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Sameer Yasir
title: Cyclone Amphan’s Death Toll Rises to 80 in India and Bangladesh
description: The worst damage was reported in the Indian state of West Bengal, home to the metropolis Kolkata and many small, coastal villages.
content: NEW DELHI — More than 80 people were killed by the powerful cyclone that slammed into India and Bangladesh on Wednesday, wiping out thousands of homes and drenching low-lying areas in torrential rain, officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: As the Restaurant Industry Struggles, the President Talks About Butter
description: A White House meeting with hospitality executives this week did little to clarify plans for millions of affected workers.
content: I once knocked on the back door of a cheesemonger in Brooklyn and waited outside for a lump of hard-to-find, extremely expensive, unmarked butter produced by Diane St. Clair at her tiny creamery in Orwell, Vt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Storytelling at the Supreme Court
description: Two recent cases on religion are about more than the tales they tell.
content: Every Supreme Court decision tells a story, its author attempting to marshal the facts and the law in such a way as to make the conclusion appear not only obvious but inevitable. A divided decision will tell two or more competing stories, which is why I usually read dissenting opinions first. That way, by the time I get around to the majority opinion, I’m aware of the alternative narrative path that could have led the court to a different destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
title: Pompeo Quietly Visits Conservative Donors and Political Figures on State Dept. Trips
description: The meetings, often kept off his public schedule, have taken place as Mike Pompeo nurtures plans for a presidential bid in 2024 and as he considered a run for the Senate from Kansas.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made a secretive trip in January to a Florida retirement enclave populated by prominent Republican donors while on the tail end of a diplomatic trip to Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Voelk
title: Rise of S.U.V.s: Leaving Cars in Their Dust, With No Signs of Slowing
description: Sport utility vehicles outsold sedans two to one in 2019, just four years after surpassing them for the first time. This shift shows little sign of stopping.
content: Trends come and go. Affordable big-screen TVs and craft beer are welcome to stay. Small-plate restaurants and leisure suits? We’ll live when they’re gone. Last year in the United States, S.U.V.s outsold sedans two to one, a trend years in the making that experts expect will only grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: How to Tell if It’s More Than Just a Bad Mood
description: It is understandable if the coronavirus pandemic has put you in a funk, but depression should be evaluated and treated.
content: For quite a while after it hit, life wasn’t bad. I had a job, at least, and was buoyed by family togetherness, by connecting and reconnecting virtually with friends. By the sensation of living through history. By walks in the park, observing fellow New Yorkers trying to fortify themselves, like I was.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Make a Great To-Do List
description: You’re stuck at home with a lot on your plate, but it’s easy to get distracted. A proper to-do list will keep you on track.
content: You’re stuck at home with a lot on your plate, but it’s easy to get distracted. A proper to-do list will keep you on track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 10 Great Bottles of Italian White Wine Under $25
description: Though noted primarily for red wine, Italy actually makes more white. These are diverse, delicious, great values and not a pinot grigio among them.
content: Regardless of the ubiquity of pinot grigio and Prosecco, the antiquated notion of Italy as solely a red wine culture retains its tenacious grip on the imagination. It was not true 20 years ago, and it’s not true today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Harold Blake, Loyal to Robert Moses Until the End, Dies at 91
description: He was executive assistant to that imperious urban planner when Mr. Moses headed the 1964-65 World’s Fair in New York. He was later an executive with the city’s bridge and tunnel authority.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: What We Can Learn From Endurance Athletes About Getting Through This Pandemic
description: Long-distance runners, cyclists and triathletes can teach us about how to move through extended periods of discomfort.
content: By now it should be clear that getting through this pandemic will be a marathon, not a sprint. But unlike marathon runners and other endurance athletes, we did not sign up to participate in this prolonged and grueling event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Teenager’s Medical Mystery
description: How the case of one 14-year-old could help doctors understand a frightening new illness linked to the coronavirus.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Woven leather accessories, provocative paintings — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are in Ardsley, N.Y., and Fairfield, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Bethenny Frankel’s Dark Journey to Find Medical Masks
description: New York officials tapped the reality television star to find masks for medical workers. She found a global bazaar of ex-cons and exaggerations.
content: It was late March, with the coronavirus starting to peak in New York and hospitals already running short on supplies, when Bethenny Frankel, the entrepreneur and reality television star, received an email from a publicist offering her access to 500 million medical masks, or about enough to fill 25 Madison Square Gardens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Sally Rowley, Jewelry Maker and Freedom Rider, Dies at 88
description: She fought for civil rights, learned to fly and sold her art on the streets of San Francisco. She died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Livestreams to Watch: John Legend Performs and Memorial Day Events
description: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for in coming days, and when to tune in.
content: Here are a few of the best events happening Thursday through Wednesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Penn Bullock and Marcus Payadue
title: Michigan, Testing, Summer Books: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: An Invitation to Share Ideas: How Will You Be Teaching Election 2020?
description: As we use the summer to plan our full calendar of election-related lesson plans, professional development webinars, and student challenges and activities, we want to hear from you.
content: How are you planning to teach the 2020 election? What can The Learning Network do to help you? And what concerns do you have, if any, about teaching this particular election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Hafner
title: Overlooked No More: When Hazel Ying Lee and Maggie Gee Soared the Skies
description: Lee and Gee never met, but as the only two Chinese-American women pilots during the war, their lives ran a strikingly similar course, and both thwarted layers of prejudice.
content: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: ‘I’m Teaching Into a Vacuum’: 14 Educators on Quarantine Learning
description: An illustrated look at how teachers across the country are reaching students during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Your Advice for the Class of 2020
description: We asked On Politics readers — alumni and new graduates — for guidance on navigating our politics.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Bill Clinton and James Patterson Are Writing a Second Book Together
description: “The President’s Daughter,” set to come out in June 2021, follows their best-selling novel “The President Is Missing.”
content: Two years after writing their first novel together, the author James Patterson and former President Bill Clinton will work on a second one, their publishers announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are You Ready to Go Back to the Office?
description: A long stretch of remote working has led companies to rethink their office space — namely, whether they need as much of it after the pandemic subsides.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sindha Agha
title: How to Be Alone
description: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.
content: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Vespoli
title: Can Coney Island Survive This?
description: A dismal season is predicted. If there is one at all.
content: This summer was supposed to be big for Coney Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Sikora
title: The Case for Music in Times of Loss
description: As a hospice chaplain, I know that the path through grief is mourning. Music can meet us on the path and help us keep walking.
content: If we’re going to survive this pandemic we need music, more than ever. There is nothing else that can meet us in our heartbreak, elevate our spirits, move us to laughter and let us dream in the way that music can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Site to Help Rescue New York Restaurants
description: The city gets its own spot on SaveTheEats, a website that highlights deals, classes and special dinners provided by kitchens navigating the pandemic.
content: An initiative called SaveTheEats is working to consolidate support for many restaurants that have closed or are struggling to remain open during the coronavirus pandemic. On Tuesday, New York City joined the growing list of participating cities on its website, including Philadelphia (where #SavePHILLYEats started on March 31), Washington, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Baltimore, Los Angeles and Austin, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Women in Charge: Success Against the Coronavirus
description: Readers discuss leadership styles and stereotypes as they speculate about why countries headed by women are seeing fewer deaths.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Abdullah al-Hamid, Saudi Dissident, Dies in Detention at 69
description: A tireless advocate for human rights and a thorn in the side of the monarchy, he spoke out for democratic reforms and was imprisoned seven times.
content: Abdullah al-Hamid, an intellectual and human-rights activist whose calls for reforming Saudi Arabia’s monarchy made him one of the kingdom’s most prominent and persistent dissidents and led to frequent prison terms, died on April 24 in detention. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lives Lost to Inaction on the Coronavirus
description: A professor compares the president to a C.E.O. who would be liable for negligent homicide if he or she knew of toxic conditions and did nothing. Also: My reopening; inspectors general; gap years.
content: To the Editor:

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: China’s Hong Kong Crackdown Could Put Trump in an Unwelcome Spot
description: A proposed new security law has senators calling for sanctions. But the president is reluctant to jeopardize his ties to President Xi Jinping.
content: WASHINGTON — China’s plans to impose sweeping new security powers over Hong Kong could inflict even more damage on already fraught relations between Washington and Beijing, and force President Trump into uncomfortable decisions about whether to maintain his self-described friendly ties with the Chinese president, Xi Jinping.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Striking Racial Divide in How Covid-19 Has Hit Nursing Homes
description: Homes with a significant number of black and Latino residents have been twice as likely to be hit by the coronavirus as those where the population is overwhelmingly white.
content: In the suburbs of Baltimore, workers at one nursing home said they were given rain ponchos to protect from infection. Twenty-seven employees at the facility, where most residents are African-American, tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: China’s ‘Crude Oil Treasure’ Promised Riches. Now Investors Owe the Bank.
description: The police are seeking to silence those who bought a Bank of China investment that backfired, highlighting the plight of small investors in the country.
content: The pitches, from one of China’s biggest and most established banks, made the investment seem like a sure bet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Flooding and a cyclone complicated efforts to keep people safe from the virus.
content: The flooding in Central Michigan and the powerful cyclone plowing into South Asia are showing us how the measures we take to be safe from one kind of calamity can heighten our danger from another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘A Towering Task’ Review: Peace and Its Discontents
description: This sweeping documentary about the Peace Corps fails to grapple with the complex ways in which humanitarian efforts can entrench nationalism.
content: “A Towering Task: The Story of the Peace Corps” opens with testimonials from alumni of the U.S. volunteer mission. When they describe the “uncomfortable” conditions of Third World countries, the film offers images of slums. When they talk about having to relinquish their American identities and empathize with “ordinary people” of other cultures, it obliges with swelling, inspirational music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Military Wives’ Review: Unlikely Choir, Familiar Frictions
description: The director of “The Full Monty” goes for that inspiring feeling again.
content: The title “Military Wives” is plain to the point of blandness. This good-hearted comedy-drama, starring Kristin Scott Thomas and Sharon Horgan, deserves a little better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Trump Rails Against Voting by Mail, States Open the Door for It
description: Despite the president’s opposition, states are increasingly reducing barriers to what many see as the safest way to vote amid the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — By threatening on Wednesday to withhold federal grants to Michigan and Nevada if those states send absentee ballots or applications to voters, President Trump has taken his latest stand against what is increasingly viewed as a necessary option for voting amid a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The First Invasion of America
description: And the cultural earthquake it’s unleashing.
content: I was an American history major in college, back in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cynthia Wachtell
title: My Son Survived Terrifying Covid-19 Complications
description: If schools reopen, how many kids won’t?
content: My 20-year-old son is a strapping 6-foot-2-inch, 190-pound man, with a permanent five o’clock shadow, palms callused from fitness training and hair on his chest. Not surprisingly, he did not fit on the small bed in the pediatric emergency room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sindha Agha
title: How to Be Alone When You’re Really Bad at It
description: I was struggling with quarantine — until I found the polar explorers.
content: My friend Kelsey doesn’t recommend getting dumped on your birthday. Valentine’s Day, I’ve heard, is also unideal. And while I can’t endorse breaking up on vacation in Hawaii with your entire family either, that ex and I do remain close friends, so perhaps there are worse ways to go than crying about irreconcilable differences over piña coladas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Shifman and Salamishah Tillet
title: How We Spend Tells Us Whose Lives Matter
description: The next federal stimulus package has to reduce inequality, not make it worse.
content: The federal coronavirus relief packages were less effective than they could have been because they ignored the ways that the pandemic would inevitably harm some communities more than others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: pratfall
description: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Strange Times, Strange Dreams
description: Are you having unusual dreams?
content: Times are strange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Saying Goodbye to Elizabeth Suzann
description: A cult label that kept things slow and simple.
content: The fashion industry is in a state of emergency. This has been made clear not only by the mounting bankruptcies of big-name retailers, but also by the closure of beloved small businesses. These are brands that won’t bounce back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Talking California With Our Newest Correspondent
description: Thursday: Meet Shawn Hubler, a longtime California journalist who’s based in Sacramento. Also: The reopening of the state picks up speed.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Thursday: Leonard Bernstein’s ‘Mass’ and ‘Trial by Fire’
description: A production of Leonard Bernstein’s argued-over “Mass” is streaming on PBS.org. And Laura Dern stars in the drama “Trial by Fire.”
content: GREAT PERFORMANCES: LEONARD BERNSTEIN MASS Stream on PBS.org. Classical music, musical theater, rock and blues (and don’t forget the marching band) all factor into Leonard Bernstein’s “Mass,” a sonic hodgepodge that first premiered in 1971. The piece mixes lyrics by the “Godspell” creator Stephen Schwartz with passages of the Latin mass liturgy. It was applauded by some and criticized by others when it debuted — and has been argued over ever since. This recorded production with the baritone Paulo Szot and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Marin Alsop offers a chance for listeners to make up their own minds on whether the piece is innovative or abrasive (or both).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Spike Lee and the Battlefield of American History
description: With his new film, the peerless American filmmaker — self-isolating and reflective in New York — unsettles past and present conflicts.
content: It’s a funny thing, Zooming with Spike Lee. He’s remote, confined within a box within a box on your computer screen, and yet somehow undiminished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: What Comes After a 2-Month Quarantine Date?
description: Sheltering at home means we’ve basically been on a date for 60 days. How will we go back to living apart?
content: My guy and I have been seeing each other since August, and our relationship is going great. For the past two months, we’ve been sheltering in place together at his home (which is 90 minutes away from mine). We’ve been having lots of fun: great conversations, making art, listening to music and still getting our work done. My question: How do we address the transition when the pandemic ends, and we inevitably go back to our normal lives (and homes)? Essentially, we’ve gone on 62 dates in 62 days!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah: Trump Will Get Crazier the Closer He Gets to Election Day
description: “I guess in Trump’s mind, voting should be like your wife smiling at you: once a year, in public, and never at home,” Noah said after Trump condemned states he alleged allowed voting by mail.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Welcome to Kiera Cass’s Kingdom, Where She Makes the Rules
description: It has been decreed: The author of the ‘Selection’ series has another best seller.
content: IN SICKNESS AND IN HEALTH “My soul is 17,” says Kiera Cass, whose latest novel, “The Betrothed,” is No. 1 on the young adult hardcover list. “I feel like if I attempted to write an adult book, it would fail miserably because I couldn’t get the voice or tone right. But writing from a young adult perspective feels incredibly natural. Thinking about the first of something — your first love, your first heartbreak, your first time learning and trying so many things, it’s just so exciting to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Bernice Silver, Impish Puppeteer and Activist, Dies at 106
description: Trained in the political theater of the 1930s, Ms. Silver was a beloved figure in the puppetry, folk music and environmental worlds.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Issues in the 2020 Presidential Race Are Most Important to You?
description: Ahead of our Civil Conversation Challenge this fall, we want to hear about the issues that young people care about most. Post your responses here all summer long.
content: Please note: This fall, as part of our menu of resources for teaching and learning about the 2020 election, we’ll be reprising our 2016 Civil Conversation Challenge, in which we asked teenagers to have productive, respectful conversations about important issues at stake in this presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: It’s Almost Memorial Day, and I Want to Go to the Beach. Can I Do That Safely?
description: As states reopen, experts say socially distant outdoor activities, like swimming or running along the shore, are some of the safer ways to re-engage with the world. Here, tips for how to enjoy the beach now.
content: As climbing temperatures herald summer’s return, cities and states around the United States are beginning the stilted process of reopening. In many places, that means a chance to return to the beach. Texas state beaches were ordered to reopen on May 1; now state beaches in Florida, Oregon and California are also starting to reopen. On the East Coast, New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Connecticut recently announced plans to reopen state beaches by the Memorial Day weekend, though with limits on capacity and other measures. (Cities, counties and other municipalities may have different restrictions; New York City’s 14 miles of public beaches, for example, remain closed.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: What Comes After a 2-Month Quarantine Date?
description: Sheltering at home means we’ve basically been on a date for 60 days. How will we go back to living apart?
content: My guy and I have been seeing each other since August, and our relationship is going great. For the past two months, we’ve been sheltering in place together at his home (which is 90 minutes away from mine). We’ve been having lots of fun: great conversations, making art, listening to music and still getting our work done. My question: How do we address the transition when the pandemic ends, and we inevitably go back to our normal lives (and homes)? Essentially, we’ve gone on 62 dates in 62 days!

title: Did de Blasio Bungle the Crisis?
description: And has the coronavirus ended food culture as we know it?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Six: Impasse
description: An interview with PewDiePie, as he comes to grips with his influence.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: Tech Is a Citadel. Del Seymour Built a Drawbridge.
description: A former drug dealer whose nonprofit helped transform the Tenderloin district joins the front lines of San Francisco’s coronavirus response.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On his walking tours of the Tenderloin, a historically seamy neighborhood named for a cut of beef, Del Seymour passes Boeddeker Park, now a verdant jewel of urbanity. Eleven years ago, it was a notorious hellhole where Mr. Seymour, then a crack addict, dealer and pimp, shooed away do-gooders from the local church because, as he put it, “I’m selling dope here and you’re disturbing my business.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Delayed Moves, Poolside Videos and Postmates Spon: The State of TikTok Collab Houses
description: Gen Z influencers are settling into life in a shuttered Los Angeles.
content: When Gianluca Conte, 20, a TikTok star with more than 2.4 million followers, left his home in Charlotte, N.C., on April 1 to move into a Los Angeles mansion with seven influencers, he didn’t expect to be largely confined to the property for months. Sure, California was under statewide stay-at-home orders, but home was where he would be working anyway — making videos with his new housemates — and the precautions had to be lifting soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A. Hope Jahren
title: I Tried to Grow a Pandemic Garden. My Strawberry Seedling Got a Virus.
description: Plants can get sick, too.
content: OSLO — A plant’s leaf is its face. If you are well acquainted with a plant, you can differentiate hunger from thirst, sickness from hale, vigor from torpor, all from the look of its leaf. Tomato leaves curl when you overwater them; sweet potato leaves spot yellow to demand magnesium. Near my desk sit hundreds of plant faces, and I search them throughout the day, hoping one will give me a reason to leave my chair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Wilson Jerman, Longtime White House Butler, Dies at 91
description: Mr. Jerman started working as a cleaner for President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1957 and retired in 2012 as an elevator operator for President Barack Obama.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathy Park Hong
title: A Season to Celebrate Asian-American Theater Is Lost to Pandemic
description: Briefly this spring New York theaters featured a stunning array of plays by writers of Asian descent. The scripts showed diversity and adventurous experimentation.
content: The cast and crew of “Wolf Play” were on their third day of tech rehearsals at Soho Rep in Manhattan in mid-March. “We were doing this complicated boxing scene, and we had the smog machine and the costumes, and it looked awesome,” said Hansol Jung, who wrote the play.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: I spent a lot of hours in the town library as a kid — my mother volunteered there, before she earned her graduate degree and became a school librarian a few towns over — and one result of all that happy browsing is that I developed a taste for the unexpected juxtaposition, the serendipity of shelving that might lead you from a book about gardening to a book about horses to a book about extrasensory perception. It wasn’t a big library; it wasn’t a big town. But it contained the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Abbott
title: What Is New York Without New York Bars?
description: I miss the promise the night offers. Liquor bottles standing sentry behind the bartender. The endless possibility in conversations overheard, lives intersecting.
content: I miss bars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nearly 1 in 4 New Yorkers Needs Food as Pandemic Persists
description: With about two million city residents thought to have inadequate food amid the coronavirus outbreak, the city will soon distribute 1.5 million meals a day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 6 Things to Do This Memorial Day Weekend
description: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch or listen to while we’re housebound.
content: As the curtain rises in Stephen Adly Guirgis’s “Our Lady of 121st Street,” a pantless man exclaims, “What kinda [expletive] world is this?” That sensational line established Guirgis as one of the most exciting voices of his generation when the play opened in 2002, and in 2020 it’s a question we might find ourselves repeating on a daily basis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Hong Kong, Cyclone Amphan, Spike Lee: Here’s what you need to know.
content: A proposal for new national security laws would give the Communist Party more control over the semiautonomous territory, and threatens to erode the freedoms that distinguish the global, commercial city from the rest of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Joan of Arc’ Review: The Saint Is Revisited in Song
description: Bruno Dumont’s movie features a young actress as the saint in her later years — along with the French pop singer Christophe.
content: The French director Bruno Dumont returns to the subject of his galvanic 2018 “Jeanette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc” in this not-quite-sequel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Bard College Music Student Sues School, Citing Instructor’s Conduct
description: The teacher was fired, but the suit says he should not have been on staff because of prior complaints by other students.
content: A music instructor at Bard College was fired this year after a Title IX investigation determined he had sexually harassed a young percussion student. Now, the student is asserting in a lawsuit against the college that the instructor should not have been on staff because of prior harassment complaints that the school knew about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Nothing Fancy’ Review: Mexican Food Through British Eyes
description: This documentary is an admiring visit with Diana Kennedy, who has devoted her life to researching and cooking traditional Mexican food.
content: No seasoning wimps need show up in the enviable kitchen of Diana Kennedy, the famed cook and British expat who has devoted most of her life to chronicling and conquering Mexican cuisine. And in Elizabeth Carroll’s debut documentary, “Diana Kennedy: Nothing Fancy,” a group of eager acolytes try not to flinch beneath her gimlet gaze and salt-seeking palate. Kennedy may be pushing her centenary, but her words are as sharp as her flavor profiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Kate Nash: Underestimate the Girl’ Review: A Star Who Fell to Earth
description: A new documentary, about the British singer-songwriter’s struggle to reassemble her pop career, is a frank depiction of the life of a workaday musician.
content: The music business takes center stage in “Kate Nash: Underestimate the Girl,” the appealingly candid documentary that finds the director Amy Goldstein working with her subject to show the financial realities of a career in pop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
title: For Spy Agencies, Briefing Trump Is a Test of Holding His Attention
description: President Trump’s intelligence briefings have gotten renewed attention since he blamed them for failing to sound the alarm early on about the coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has blamed many others for his administration’s flawed response to the coronavirus: China, governors, the Obama administration, the World Health Organization. In recent weeks, he has also faulted the information he received from an obscure analyst who delivers his intelligence briefings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Many Jobs May Vanish Forever as Layoffs Mount
description: With over 38 million U.S. unemployment claims in nine weeks, one economist says the situation is “grimmer than we thought.”
content: Even as states begin to reopen for business, a further 2.4 million workers joined the nation’s unemployment rolls last week, and there is growing concern among economists that many of the lost jobs are gone for good.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Many Facebook Employees to Work From Home Permanently
description: Unemployment Claims Continue to Rise in U.S.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow live market developments here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: New Threat to New York City: Commercial Rent Payments Plummet
description: One landlord reported that 80 percent of retail tenants missed rent. The drop in commercial rent payments could imperil property tax collections that pay for city services.
content: In Brooklyn, a nightclub has been closed for two months. In Manhattan, a travel agency says it is unlikely to ever reopen. Both have not paid rent since the coronavirus shutdowns began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Boris Johnson Avoids Criminal Inquiry Into His Dealings as London’s Mayor
description: A police watchdog did find evidence, however, that Mr. Johnson and an American businesswoman may have had an “intimate relationship” and that the relationship helped her secure money and networking opportunities.
content: LONDON — A British police watchdog agency said on Thursday that it would not conduct a criminal investigation into Prime Minister Boris Johnson over claims that as mayor of London he had done official favors for an American businesswoman whose apartment he sometimes visited during working hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Markoff
title: A Case for Cooperation Between Machines and Humans
description: A computer scientist argues that the quest for fully automated robots is misguided, perhaps even dangerous. His decades of warnings are gaining more attention.
content: The Tesla chief Elon Musk and other big-name Silicon Valley executives have long promised a car that can do all the driving without human assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: As the Nation Begins Virus Tracing, It Could Learn From This N.J. City
description: Paterson, a low-income city of 150,000, has been a pioneer in creating a contact-tracing program to curb the spread of the coronavirus.
content: PATERSON, N.J. — The Uber driver had lost his sense of smell and taste but otherwise felt fine. He kept driving passengers in this small, industrial city until last week, when he took a test for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s Inaccurate Claims on Hydroxychloroquine
description: The president falsely described scientific research around the malaria drug, falsely denied the existence of a federal warning against it and argued, with no evidence, that large numbers of health care workers were taking it.
content: As President Trump has promoted hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for the coronavirus and claimed to be taking it himself, he has continued to make inaccurate or incomplete statements about the drug. Here is a fact check of his recent claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Delayed Moves, Poolside Videos and Postmates Spon: The State of TikTok Collab Houses
description: Gen Z influencers are settling into life in a shuttered Los Angeles.
content: When Gianluca Conte, 20, a TikTok star with more than 2.4 million followers, left his home in Charlotte, N.C., on April 1 to move into a Los Angeles mansion with seven influencers, he didn’t expect to be largely confined to the property for months. Sure, California was under statewide stay-at-home orders, but home was where he would be working anyway — making videos with his new housemates — and the precautions had to be lifting soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A. Hope Jahren
title: I Tried to Grow a Pandemic Garden. My Strawberry Seedling Got a Virus.
description: Plants can get sick, too.
content: OSLO — A plant’s leaf is its face. If you are well acquainted with a plant, you can differentiate hunger from thirst, sickness from hale, vigor from torpor, all from the look of its leaf. Tomato leaves curl when you overwater them; sweet potato leaves spot yellow to demand magnesium. Near my desk sit hundreds of plant faces, and I search them throughout the day, hoping one will give me a reason to leave my chair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathy Park Hong
title: A Season to Celebrate Asian-American Theater Is Lost to Pandemic
description: Briefly this spring New York theaters featured a stunning array of plays by writers of Asian descent. The scripts showed diversity and adventurous experimentation.
content: The cast and crew of “Wolf Play” were on their third day of tech rehearsals at Soho Rep in Manhattan in mid-March. “We were doing this complicated boxing scene, and we had the smog machine and the costumes, and it looked awesome,” said Hansol Jung, who wrote the play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Wilson Jerman, Longtime White House Butler, Dies at 91
description: Mr. Jerman started working as a cleaner for President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1957 and retired in 2012 as an elevator operator for President Barack Obama.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is New York Without New York Bars?
description: I miss the promise the night offers. Liquor bottles standing sentry behind the bartender. The endless possibility in conversations overheard, lives intersecting.
content: I miss bars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: I spent a lot of hours in the town library as a kid — my mother volunteered there, before she earned her graduate degree and became a school librarian a few towns over — and one result of all that happy browsing is that I developed a taste for the unexpected juxtaposition, the serendipity of shelving that might lead you from a book about gardening to a book about horses to a book about extrasensory perception. It wasn’t a big library; it wasn’t a big town. But it contained the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nearly 1 in 4 New Yorkers Needs Food as Pandemic Persists
description: With about two million city residents thought to have inadequate food amid the coronavirus outbreak, the city will soon distribute 1.5 million meals a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: ‘Horrified’ and ‘Ashamed’: Volkswagen Apologizes for Ad
description: The German car company withdrew an online ad that attracted criticism for its racist images.
content: In the brief video, a dark-skinned man is pushed off a city street and onto a sidewalk by a giant white hand. Then another giant hand takes him by the head and pushes him toward a doorway, before he is summarily flicked inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Prominent Scientists Denounce End to Coronavirus Grant
description: A group of 77 Nobel laureates wants the U.S. government to review a grant cancellation for research in China directly related to preventing pandemics.
content: A group of 77 Nobel laureates has asked for an investigation into the cancellation of a federal grant to EcoHealth Alliance, a group that researches bat coronaviruses in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer, Michael Levenson and Katie Benner
title: Shooting at Texas Base Was ‘Terrorism Related,’ F.B.I. Says
description: The gunman was killed, and a member of the base’s security force was injured in the attack at an entrance to Naval Air Station Corpus Christi, the authorities said.
content: An attack by a gunman who opened fire early Thursday at a gate of Naval Air Station Corpus Christi in Texas was related to terrorism, the F.B.I. said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Giovanni Russonello
title: A Campaign Milestone: ‘I Was Drugged and Raped,’ Heard in a Candidate’s Ad
description: A Democratic congressional candidate in Virginia is releasing a TV spot where she speaks candidly about assault, a new step in a political landscape altered by the #MeToo movement.
content: The photo could have been taken at any prom or sorority formal. Girls with long hair and fancy dresses, their arms draped around one another’s shoulders, smiling wide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher, Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: China Moves to Tighten Its Control of Hong Kong
description: New security laws would allow Beijing to take aim at the protests that have roiled the semiautonomous city and posed a direct challenge to the Communist Party and its leader, Xi Jinping.
content: BEIJING — China signaled on Thursday it would move forward with laws that would take aim at antigovernment protests and other dissent in Hong Kong. It is the clearest message yet that the Communist Party is moving to undermine the civil liberties the semiautonomous territory has known since the 1997 British handoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Safran Foer
title: The End of Meat Is Here
description: If you care about the working poor, about racial justice, and about climate change, you have to stop eating animals.
content: Is any panic more primitive than the one prompted by the thought of empty grocery store shelves? Is any relief more primitive than the one provided by comfort food?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: What Happens to Hong Kong Now?
description: What could China’s move to strengthen control over Hong Kong with new security laws yield? And why did it propose this now? Some answers to these and other questions.
content: When Britain returned Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty, in a 1997 handover agreement that ended an era of British colonialism dating to the Opium Wars, China’s top leader at the time, Deng Xiaoping, guaranteed Hong Kong’s way of life for at least 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times
